verses.verse: ((2 Job describeth the wickedness of men, and showeth what curse belongeth to the wicked.12 How all things are governed by God’s providence.17 And the destruction of the wicked.) ) How should not the times (Thus Job speaketh in his passions, and after the judgment of the flesh: that is, that he seeth not the things that are done at times, neither yet hath a peculiar care over all, because he punisheth not the wicked, nor revengeth the godly.) be hid from the Almighty, seeing that they which know him, see not his (When he punisheth the wicked, and rewardeth the good.) days?
Some remove the landmarks, that rob the flocks and feed thereof.
They lead away the ass of the fatherless, and take the widow’s ox to pledge.
They make the poor to turn out of the way, so that the poor of the earth hide themselves (And for cruelty and oppression dare not show their faces.) together.

Behold, others as wild asses in the wilderness, go forth to their business, and (That is, spareth diligence.) rise early for a prey: the wilderness (He and his live by robbing and murdering.) giveth him and his children food.
They reap (Meaning, the poor man’s.) his provision in the field, but they gather the late (Signifying, that one wicked man will not spoil another, but for necessity.) vintage of the wicked.
They cause the naked to lodge without garment, and without covering in the cold.
They are wet with the showers of the mountains, (The poor are driven by the wicked into the rocks and holes where they cannot lie dry for the rain.) and they embrace the rock for want of a covering.

They pluck the fatherless (That is, they so powle and pill the poor widow, that she cannot have to sustain herself that she may be able to give her child suck.) from the breast, and take the pledge of (That is, his garment, wherewith he should be covered or clad.) the poor.
They cause him to go naked without clothing, and take the gleaning from the hungry.

They that make oil (In such places which are appointed for that purpose: meaning, that those that labor for the wicked, are pined for hunger.) between their walls, and tread their winepresses, suffer thirst.

Men (For the great oppression and extortion.) cry out of the city, and the souls of the slain (Cry out and call for vengeance.) cry out: yet God (God doth not condemn the wicked, but seemeth to pass over it by his long silence.) doth not charge them with folly.
These are they that abhor the (That is, God’s word, because they are reproved thereby.) light: they know not the ways thereof, nor continue in the paths thereof.
The murderer riseth early, and killeth the poor and the needy: and in the night he is as a thief.

The eye also of the (By these particular vices and the licence thereunto, he would prove that God punished not the wicked, and rewardeth the just.) adulterer waiteth for the twilight, and saith, None eye shall see me, and disguiseth his face.
They dig through houses in the dark, which they marked for themselves in the day: they know not the light.
But the morning is even to them as the shadow of death: if one know them, they are in the terrors of the shadow of death.

He is swift upon the (He fleeth to the waters for his succor.) waters: their (They think that all the world is bent against them, and dare not go by the high way.) portion shall be cursed in the earth: he will not behold the way of the vineyards.
As the dry ground and heat consume the snow waters, so shall the grave (As the dry ground is never full with waters, so will they never cease sinning till they come to the grave.) the sinners.

(Though God suffer the wicked for a time, yet their end shall be most vile destruction, and in this point Job commiteth to himself, and showeth his confidence.) The pitiful man shall forget him: the worm shall feel his sweetness: he shall be no more remembered, and the wicked shall be broken like a tree.
He (He showeth why the wicked shall not be lamented, because he did not pity others.) doth evil entreat the barren that doth not bear, neither doeth he good to the widow.

He draweth also the (He declareth that after that the wicked have destroyed the weakest, they will do like to the stranger, and therefore are justly punished by God’s judgments.) mighty by his power, and when he riseth up, none is sure of life.
Though men give him assurance to be in safety, yet his eyes are upon their ways.
They are exalted for a little, but they are gone, and are brought low as all others: they are destroyed, and cut off as the top of an ear of corn.

But if it be not (That is, that contrary to your reasoning no man can give perfect reasons of God’s judgments, let me be reproved.) so, where is he? or who will prove me a liar, and make my words of no value?
